title: Dashboard_1
text:
Data from datahub.io
Including population figures for countries, regions (e.g. Asia) and the world. Data comes originally from World Bank and has been converted into standard CSV. Data

Load Package and Data


library(broom)
library(tidyverse)
library(magrittr)
pop_data <- read.csv("population_csv.csv")


Show the world population by year


# Filter the Data
pop_all <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "WLD")

#Visualize
ggplot(pop_all, aes(x = Year, y = Value)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "World Population", x = "Year", y = "Population")





Show the US population growth per year by percentage


# Filter the Data
pop_USA <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "USA")%>%
    mutate(percentage = c(0,(diff(Value) /head(Value, -1))*100))


#Visualize
ggplot(pop_USA, aes(x = Year, y = percentage)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "US Population", x = "Year", y = "Population Growth(%)")





linear model prediction for Chinese population next 10 years


# Filter the Data
pop_CHN <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "CHN")
Year <- pop_CHN$Year
Value <- pop_CHN$Value
# predict
model <- lm(Value ~ Year, data=pop_CHN)
future_years <- data.frame(Year=seq(max(Year)+1, max(Year)+10, 1))
predictions <- predict(model, newdata = future_years)
print(predictions)

         1          2          3          4          5          6          7 
1480990637 1494269723 1507548809 1520827896 1534106982 1547386068 1560665154 
         8          9         10 
1573944241 1587223327 1600502413 



pie chart for China, Japan,and South Korea population in East Asia & Pacific in 2015


#get 2015 data
pop_data2015 <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Year == 2015)
pop_CJK2015 <- pop_data2015 %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "CHN" | Country.Code == "JPN" | Country.Code == "KOR")
pop_EAS2015 <- pop_data2015 %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "EAS")

pop_Other <- pop_EAS2015$Value - sum(pop_CJK2015$Value)

pie_data <- rbind(pop_CJK2015, data.frame(Country.Name = "Other", Country.Code = "OTH", Year = 2015 ,Value = pop_Other))
# draw pie chart
ggplot(pie_data, aes(x = "", y = Value, fill = Country.Name)) +
  geom_bar(width = 1, stat = "identity") +
  coord_polar("y", start = 0) +
  theme_void() +
  labs(fill = "Country", title = "Population_distribution") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Pastel1")

title: About
text:
Welcome to my first data science blog! It’s Jiajun Zhang here. And you can call me Acedia or Acky as well. If you find Jiajun is hard to pronounce.


Currently, I am enrolled as a student in the Master of Science in Information Management (MSIM) program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC).


This blog is a course project.


I consider myself a dedicated thinker who thrives on tackling intricate problems and developing innovative solutions to enhance model performance and interpretability. For leisure, I like to play card games like bridge.


Your interest and engagement are greatly appreciated.
